title: Generalizing the correctness of transactional memory
abstract: Transactional memory (TM) is a promising paradigm for concurrent programming in the multi-core era. It provides programmers a simple and familiar tool—transactions—and gives opportunities to execute those transactions concurrently in a scalable way. Ideally, programs could execute all operations on shared data within transactions, and optionally some operations on thread-local data non-transactionally. In practice, however, not all operations on shared data can be wrapped in transactions because of either performance concerns or requirements of interoperability with legacy software components. It is thus not surprising to see a large body of research dedicated to exploring the various models of interactions between transactions and non-transactional code, and implementing those models, eg,[6, 2, 7, 1]. The mutual interaction between transactions is formalized by the notion of opacity [3], which is indeed ensured by most TM implementations. Opacity requires that transactions should “look like” they executed in some sequential order, consistent with their real-time order, and no transaction (even an aborted one) should ever observe an inconsistent state of the system. At a high-level, this gives programmers an illusion that there is no concurrency between transactions, which resembles the intuitive model of critical sections protected by a single global lock. The interactions between non-transactional operations are expressed using a memory model. While a TM can be implemented in a way to ensure opacity for transactions, there is little one can do (on a given platform or run-time environment) to change the underlying memory model …

title: Design and simulation of a modified monocone antenna for Ultra Wide Bandwidth
abstract: This paper describes the design and simulation of an Ultra Wide Band omni-directional antenna. The bandwidth of this antenna covers S, C, ext. C and X band frequencies. This bandwidth has been achieved by making a simple and easy modification in the design of a classical conical monopole (monocone) antenna. The achieved simulated results show stable radiation pattern over a specified field of view and impedance bandwidth for VSWR less than 2.0 is over the frequency band of 2-14 GHz. The bandwidth of monocone is computed, compared and optimized with respect to the radiation pattern of a thin monopole antenna.

title: Diversity for fatty acid composition of advanced breeding lines of Indian mustard (Brassica juncea (L.) Czern & Coss)
abstract: Revised: May 2008; Accepted: July 2008) and oleic acid (C18. 1) is 21.6: 10: 3.1%, respectively [2]. Hence cultivars with low linolenic acid and high oleic acid coupled with low erucic acid (< 2%) content are being developed. Considerable variability for different fatty acids has been reported in Indian mustard [3, 4]. And now all the advanced breeding lines are screened for their fatty acid composition together with yield performance for their release as new varieties.Fifty six advanced breeding lines selected for superior oil quality (ie low erucic acid in oil)[twelve PRQ (RC-78J x Zem-1), thirty three PLEM (Kranti x Zem-1), three DL [(BJ-1058 x Kranti) x (RC-781 x Zem-l)] and eight LG (BJ-1058 x Kranti)] along with three checks viz. Kranti and Pusa Karisma and PRQ-2005-1 (registered donor for low erucic acid IC-546946) were grown in Augmented Block Design in eight blocks and all the recommended cultural practices were performed in rabi 2005-06 and rabi 2006-07. Self seeds from all the advanced lines and checks were harvested upon maturity. Days to maturity for each advanced line were recorded. Mature seeds were dried in hot air oven at 60oC till they become moisture free and 1000 seed weight was taken with the help of numerical seed counter and electronic balance. The oil content (%) in seeds was determined by Newport Analyzer-4000 based on the principle of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR). Fatty acid methyl esters were prepared from the seeds of each line using bulk seed method by crushing 10-15 seeds of each line in petroleum ether and were esterified using IN Sodium Methoxide [5] and the supernatant was taken and …

title: Management of root-knot nematode, Meloidogyne incognita infecting pigeon pea
abstract: Root-knot nematodes, Meloidogyne spp. have world wide distribution and are major pests of various crops. The present paper takes into account the plant growth parameters and nematode multiplication in response to nematicides under pot conditions. Experiment was conducted in glass house at temperature range between 22-3.5 C. Sterilized sandy loam soil and compost in the ratio of 3: 1 were treated with two nematicides viz./carbofutan 3G and phorate 10G@ 1.5 and 1.0 kg ai/ha. The treated soils were filled in 15 cm earthern pots. Seeds of pigeonpea cv. Bahar were surface sterilized with 0.1% Hg2Cl2, thoroughly washed four times with sterilized water, and sown after one day of application of nematicides in pots. After germination, seedlings were thinned to single healthy plant/pot. One week old plants were inoculated with freshly hatched 500 second-stage juveniles of Meloidogyne incognita per pot at the …

title: Sugar technology-Selection of a suitable buffer for ICUMSA color determination at pH= 6.4
abstract: A scientifically established pH (6.4) method of sugar color determination has been developed and was discussed at the Brazil Session of ICUMSA (2006). The suitability of buffers to stabilize the pH of sugar solutions at pH 6.4 was investigated by employing the following buffers, viz., MES, MOPSO and MOPS. Using cellulose ester filters with a 0.80 μm followed by 0.45 μm pore size, turbidity was minimized. MES buffer showed excellent pH stabilization at pH 6.4 and limited color alteration. On the basis of these preliminary investigations, it is suggested that the use of MES buffer for pH adjustment in the measurement of all types of sugar colors be subjected to collaborative testing by ICUMSA as per the IUPAC protocol. The method format as per the IUPAC protocol has been given in the text. Based on the authors’ proposal, a domestic collaborative study is underway under the auspices of Indian National Committee of …

title: Ewe productivity efficiency of single and multiple lambs bearing of Garole, Malpura and their crossbred ewes
abstract: Comparative evaluation of ewes of Garole x Malpura (GM) halfbreds bearing single, twin and triplet lambs with the contemporary Malpura and Garole was made in this study to decide future breeding and selection strategy. Data collected on ewe productive efficiency of 561 Malpura, 227 Garole and 211 of GM ewes maintained at the Central Sheep and Wool Research Institute, Avikanagar, during year 2000 to 2004 were used for present study. The GM ewes bearing twin and triplet lambs weaned 2.71 and 12.76% more litter weight over Malpura and at 12 months of age corresponding figures were 19.83 and 20.94, respectively. The ewe productivity of GM bearing twin and triplet lambs in terms of per kg body weight of ewe was 0.630 and 0.651 kg at weaning and 1.414 and 1.346 kg at 12 months of age, respectively, while litter weight harvested from Malpura ewes per kg body weight of ewe at weaning and 12 …

title: In Vitro Effects of Certain Membrane-acting Agents on Superoxide and Hydrogen Peroxide Production, Protein Synthesis and Membrane ATPase Activity in Buffalo …
abstract: Polymorphonuclear (PMN) cells play a key role in innate immunity, due to their ability to produce reactive oxidants such as superoxide (O2–) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and to release antimicrobial proteins and peptides stored in their lysosomal granules. In the present study, the effects of the activation of buffalo PMN cells with various membrane-acting agents were evaluated in terms of O2– and H2O2 production, the activities of membrane ATPases, and protein synthesis. Studies involving the incorporation of 35S-methionine revealed significant protein-synthesising ability in resting PMN cells and in cells treated with lipopolysaccharide (LPS), as well as with opsonised zymosan (OZ). Protein synthesis, as judged by fluorography of the cytosolic fraction, showed more than 12 bands, whilst the cytoskeletal fraction showed 2–3 bands. PMN activation with concanavalin A (ConA), digitonin and sodium …

title: Spontaneous knotting of ryles tube in a post operative patient
abstract: Spontaneous knotting of nasogastric tube is a rare complication. A similar case encountered in a postoperative patient is reported.

title: Anti-inflammatory activity of Gloriosa superba Linn
abstract: Anti-inflammatory activity of alcoholic, hydroalcoholic, aqueous extracts of Gloriosa superba Linn, tubers were evaluated in male albino rats. The experimental model used was carrageenan induced rat paw edema. 1 Indomethacin (I0mg/kg., po) was used as standard Alcoholic, hydroalcoholic and aqueous extracts were given orally in the dosages of 250 mg/kg. All the three extracts were found to have significant (P< 0.01) anti-inflammatory activity. The aqueous extract of G. superba Linn, tubers was found to have best anti-inflammatory activity.

title: Evaluation of Physico-Chemical Parameters and Suitability of Industrial Wastewater and Ground Water for Irrigation
abstract: This manuscript presents a comparative styudy of physico-chemical properties and Suitability of industrial wastewater and groundwater for irrigation. Groundwater and wastewater samples from Amanisha nala and hand pump of seven industrial areas and adjacent localities of Jaipur city were analyzed during monsoon session (June, 2002 to Sep., 2002) with the help of standard methods of APHA and Black. From the observations, it may inferred that the concentration of pH, Ca super(2+), Mg super(2+), SO super(2) sub(4) super(-), CO, super(2-), TH, DO and F- are within permissible limits of ISI, ICMR & WHO, but TDS, EC, BOD and COD values show that poor water quality in most of the studied groundwater and industrial wastewater samples taken from various industrial sites.

title: Management of Heterodera cajani on pigeonpea with nematicides and organic amendments
abstract: Use of organic amendments is one of the practical approaches not only for the management of nematode pests but also in substituting the hazardous pesticides. Integration ofnematicides and organic amendments are very good tool for every way. The present investigation was undertaken to know the efficacy of nematicides

title: Virial coefficients from equation of state
abstract: This paper presents the theoretical prediction of second, third and fourth virial coefficients of linear hard chain molecules employing equations of state. The equations of state are determined through statistical associating fluid theory (SAFT). Two improvements of SAFT theory as SAFT-Dimer and SAFT-Trimer are employed to determine the virial coefficients. The SAFT-Trimer model predicts the virial coefficients much closer to the pearl-necklace model in comparison to the SAFT-Dimer model, concluding thereby that the SAFT-Trimer model seems more flexible in comparison to that of the dimer model.

title: EFFECT OF MIXED BIO-FERTILIZERS AND NITROGEN LEVELS ON GROWTH, YIELD ATTRIBUTES AND YIELD OF PEARLMILLET
abstract: A field experiment was conducted at Research farm of CCS Haryana Agricultural University, Hisar during kharif 2002. Nine treatments viz., control, seed inoculation with mixed bio-fertilizers, 50 RDN, 75% RDN, 100% RDN, 125% RDN, 50% RDN+ mixed biofertilizers, 75% RDN+ mixed bio-fertilizers and 100% RDN+ mixed bio-fertilizers were tested in randomized block design with four replications. Application of 125% RD resulted in significantly higher grain and stover yield except 100% RDN, 75% RDN+ mixed bio-fertilizer and 100% RDN+ mixed bio-fertilizer. However, stover yield in 75% RDN+ mixed bio-fertilizer significantly increased the grain and stover yieldover control

title: Uterine fibroids: A clinical study with USG follow-up
abstract: A total of two hundred are seventeen cases of uterine fibroids (single and multiple) were registered and available for proper followup of treatment. Analysis was made to assess the percent response in each case following treatment with homoeopathic remedies at Gaurang Clinic and Centre for Homoeopathic Research, Lucknow till December 31,2002. Timely diagnosis by Ultrasonography followed by treatment with homoeopathy showed excellent response in significant number of cases avoiding surgery which has been the lone option in modern system of medicine. After homoeopathic treatment seventy four patients were cured, twenty one patients were best improving showing more than 50% reduction in size of fibroid sixty four patients showed significant improvement thirty one maintained status quo and twenty one patients did not improve. Status could not be reliably evaluated in four cases due to confusing …

title: Relative wool production and quality performance of elite flock of Marwari sheep
abstract: Data on 1242 animals of elite and tester flocks of Marwari breed were scrutinized to assess the influence of various factors on adult and lambs' clips and wool quality parameters. The overall least squares means of adult spring, autumn and annual and lambs' first and second six monthly greasy fleece production were 899.26±5.68 g, 481.83±4.66 g, 1379.97±8.05 g, 577.73±5.81 g and 586.55±8.53 g. The overall least squares means of wool quality parameters were 36.15±0.27 μ, 32.77±0.61%, 18.34±0.42%, 51.22±0.73%, 4.69±0.05 cm and 0.56±0.01 per cm., respectively for fibre diameter, hetero fibres, hairy fibres, medullation, staple length and crimp. Group had highly significant effect on lambs' first clip, fibre diameter and crimp. Sex showed highly significant influence on adult clips, staple length and crimp and significant influence on hairy fibres. The effect of year was found to be highly significant on all adult and …

title: Powertrain transfer path analysis of a truck
abstract: A project to perform a powertrain Noise Path Analysis (NPA) on a two-wheel rear drive vehicle was performed at Visteon Corporation. Research engineers gained insight into the NPA procedure as applied to a typical medium-duty production pick-up truck. Visteon's interest in this project was two folded. First, to do a full experimental Noise Path analysis (NPA) and then, develop a methodology to integrate the experimental measurements and analytical results into a unified model to predict the responses at passenger interface points within a vehicle. This presentation will cover the details of the experimental NPA including measurement locations, transducer types and placement, elastomeric mount characterization, and the matrix inversion process required for indirect force estimation. Both the direct mount method and the indirect force methods based on matrix inversions were used for several mount locations to allow the estimated forces from two independent methods to be compared for accuracy and verification. Finally, subsets of forces were estimated from analytical models and compared to the experimentally determined forces. This process allows Visteon to predict passenger response interface point amplitudes from a combination of their Finite Element Powertrain models and P/F body measurements supplied by the OEM to characterize the transfer paths. This process gives Visteon the ability to enhance their driveline subsystem NVH performance relative to the sensitivities for the receiving body structure. title: A case study of the effect of free and assertive movement of male agricultural labour on rural labour market in Gwalior district, Madhya Pradesh
abstract: Until recently agriculture was the main source of hired human labour employment but now the situation is changing fast and a chunk of rural labour, especially male labour has shown a significant movement from agricultural occupations to non-agricultural operations. On the basis of labour use pattern during 1998-99, treating 1988-89 as base year, data were collected from 120 rural labour households spread in 12 sample villages in Gwalior district with a view to examine their employment behaviour and its effect on rural labour market. The study revealed that partial mechanisation of certain farm operations in crop production and their capital resources use had resulted in a reduction of 14 per cent in agricultural labour use per farm within a period of ten years (1988-89 to 1998-99). Among the hired agricultural labour use, male labour had recorded very fast reduction while female labour showed only a marginal …

title: Boron and manganese nutrition of wheat in Entisols
abstract: Response to both Band Mn in wheat has been reported by Agarwala and Yadav (1984) and Singh (1990), respectively. Both synergistic and antagonistic interrelationships ofB and Mn, when applied together to different crops have been reported (Reddy et 01. 1987). The continuous use of particular nutrient may influence the nutrient balance in soil which affects crop yields adversely. Therefore, keeping the above in view, the present investigation was undertaken under greenhouse conditions using wheat as a test crop. A pot culture experiment was conducted on a sandy loam soil (Typic Ustipsamment) having following characteristics: pH 8.3, organic carbon 4.6 g kg-', Ee 0.36 dS m", DTPA-Mn 2.80 mg kg-'and hot water soluble B 0.30 mg kg-'soil. Eight kg of air-dried soil was filled in polyethylene-lined earthen pots. Treatments consisted of four levels each ofMn (0.0, 2.5, 5.0 and 10.0 mg kg") and B (0.0, 0.5, 1.0 and …

title: Temporal changes in participation of women in different farm and non-farm activities in Haryana
abstract: The study attempts to examine the educational status and the extent of participation of men and women in different farm and non-farm activities in three randomly selected cluster of villages in Hisar district of Haryana at two points of time, 1985-86 and 1997-98. The study revealed that 14 per cent of the adult female members and about 10 per cent of the adult male members of sample farms were engaged in wage earning activity. Of the remaining members, 86 per cent of both adult male and female workers participated in own farm activities; about four per cent of the male members were engaged in own farm and wage earning activities. No female member owning land was found doing wage earning activity. The level of education of female members was very low as 92 per cent were illiterates as compared to 85 per cent of male population. Over time there was slight improvement in literacy of both males and …

title: Irrigability and productivity classifications of some typical soils of sedentary and alluvial origins
abstract: Six pedons occurring in a spatially differing area between Ranchi in south (sedentaly) and Madhubani in north Bihar (alluvial) were studied for evaluating irrigability and productivity potentials. The soils differed in irrigability classes and the differences are related to various soil limitations. Both, land and soil irrigability classes, show alignment with each other in their broader perspective. Pedons 1, 4, 5 and 6 fall under good productivity class whereas pedon 2 has average and pedon 3 poor productivity. The potential productivity class is excellent for pedons 4, 5 and 6 whereas good for pedons 1 and 2 but poor for pedon 3. The coefficient of productivity follows the order: Pedon 6> Pedon 2> Pedon 1 > Pedon 5> Pedon 4 > Pedon 3. These findings enable database to execute the reliable decision for effective land use planning and help to resolve the contrast on land surface significantly for maximizing production.

title: Effect of different factors on movement of sulfate in soils of semiarid regions of India
abstract: Effects of soil texture, application rates of sulfate, initial water content, water application rates, and water management regimes on movement of sulfate were studied in a series of laboratory experiments in three soils. Soils in the plexiglass columns were compacted to 1.45 g cm‐3 bulk density in each column, and K2SO4 was applied as a source of sulfate. In a sulfate application rate experiment, 100, 200, and 400 μg, and in other experiments, 100 μg SO4                2‐ ‐S g‐1 soil was applied in the top 3‐cm soil layer. To 120‐cm‐long columns, 2.5, 5, and 10 cm of water was applied in a water application rate experiment, 10 cm of water in a water management regime experiment, and in the rest of the experiments, 5 cm of water was applied. Different rates of sulfate application did not change the leaching behavior, and sulfate moved to 27‐cm depth at all applied sulfate concentrations when 5 cm of water was …

abstract: see more details cv. Bahar were inoculated with H. cajani and F. udum either alone or simultaneously in a greenhouse experiment. H. cajani enhanced the percentage of wilting when inoculated in combination with F. udum with maximum reduction in plant growth and wilt incidence occurring when H. cajani was inoculated 10 days prior to F. udum. When inoculated together, F. udum reduced the multiplication of H. cajani.

title: Evaluation of Extractants for Availability of Soil Manganese to Oats
abstract: Some soil test methods were evaluated for predicting response of oats to manganese in alluvial soils. DTPA-CaCl2 was found to be most promising extractant in view of its high relationship with uptake of Mn by plants and relative yield. The critical limit was 6.8 ppm to Mn application and critical Mn concentration in oat plants was 28.0 ppm.

title: Staff nurses: role perception and role performance.
abstract: The present study was conducted to investigate the relationship between role perception and role-performance. A sample of three hundred Staff Nurses was drawn from a Central Government hospital of Delhi. To assess role perception and role performance, a role perception questionnaire and a role performance inventory were administered respectively to each subject individually. The results indicated that inner-directed role perception had a negative relationship with role performance. Other directed role perception had a significant positive relationship with role performance. To achieve job success, Staff Nurses seemingly can concentrate on other directed role perception.

title: Tectonic stability of the Farakka dam and its adjoining regions in east India
abstract: The results of gravity, magnetic and seismic surveys carried out in the neighbourhood of the Farakka dam in east India are presented. A major deep-seated fault, extending from Kishanganj to south of Malda, has been inferred from gravity data. This fault runs ∼ 20 km east of the Farakka dam, with a north-south trend. Magnetic anomalies over this region are strong and show tight closures. This could indicate the presence of basaltic lava at shallow depths. P-wave velocities vary from 4.6 to 5.6 km s−1 at depths from 35 to 250 m. Borehole data support these findings. Magnetic and seismic observations do not support the fault inferred from gravity data.

title: Propagation of exponential shock waves in magnetogasdynamics
abstract: Self-similar flows of a perfect gas behind the cylindrical shock wave propagating exponentially in an atmosphere whose density varies inversely as the fourth power of shock radius are investigated. The effects of radiation flux has also been taken into consideration. The total energy of the wave is constant.

title: Fungicidal activity of essential plant oils.
abstract: Collistemon lanceolatus, Eucalyptus sp. Artemisia vulgaris, Ageratum sp. Lantana camara and Ocimum sanctum plant parts on steam distillation produced essential oils. Antifungal activity of the oils was seen against Aspergillus flavus, Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus parasiticus, Helminthosporium oxysporum and Trichoderma viride . Essential oil of Eucalyptus, Ageratum and Ocimum have remarkable antifungal activity.

title: Heat and mass transfer in rotating fluid with Hall current, I
abstract: Hall effects on the hydromagnetic free convection resulting from the combined effects of thermal and mass diffusion of an electrically conducting liquid past an infinite vertical porous plate in a rotating system have been analysed. The expressions for the mean velocity, mean temperature in the boundary layer and the mean skin friction, the mean rate of heat transfer on the plate are derived. The effects of magnetic parameterM, Hall parameterm, Schmidt number Sc, and Ekman numberE on the flow field, are discussed with the help of graphs and tables.

abstract: Indiscriminate topical use of antibiotics espicially tetracycline and steriods has effected the normal symbiosis between the bacteria and fungi. The suppression of bacterial growth encourages proliferation of the fungi.[1],[2]

title: Seasonal abundance of tea mosquito (Helopeltis antonii Sign.) on cashew in relation to meteorological factors
abstract: Seasonal fluctuations in the population density of tea mosquito, Helopeltis antonii Signoret, were studied during June 1972 to May 1977 at weekly intervals. The build up of pest population commenced in October-November synchronising with the emergence of new flushes in cashew after the cessation of monsoon showers. The pest population reached its peak in January. Tea mosquito was active in the field in different degrees of intensity till May. The population build up of the pest was found to be negatively correlated with the meteorological factors like minimum temperature, minimum relative humidity and rainfall and positively with sunshine. The most favourable period for the rapid multiplication and population build up of the pest was between December to February. During the monsoon season, tea mosquito population was totally absent.

title: Field evaluation of the efficacy of four insecticides in the control of tea mosquito
abstract: The adults and nymphs of tea mosquito Helopeltis antonii Sign. suck sap from the tender shoots, freshly emerged leaves, inflorescences, immature nuts and developing apples. The injury made by this pest results in drying up of the new flushes, giving scorched up appearance to the trees, shirivelling and falling of the immature nuts of different stages. The need for an alternative insecticide has often been felt in the past as sometimes endosulfan which is effective in controlling tea mosquito was not readily available in certain cashew growing areas.

title: Synthesis and Physical Properties of 3-Penten-2-ol Derivatives of Some Elements
abstract: The 3-penten-2-ol derivative of germanium Ge [OCH(CH3)CH=CHCH3]4 has been synthesized by the reaction of germanium tetrachloride with the alcohol using ammonia as hydrogen chloride acceptor. Similar derivatives of boron, aluminium, titanium, niobium, tantalum and butyltin have been synthesized by the alcohol interchange reactions of the corresponding metal alkoxides (ethoxide or isopropoxide) with 3-penten-2-ol in the appropriate molar ratio. The new compounds have been characterized by metal analyses, molecular weights, IR and PMR spectral studies.

title: Studies on regeneration in Ceratopteris thalictroides
abstract: Entire detached juvenile leaves up to third order and roots from sexually produced young sporophytes of Ceratopteris thalictroides were aseptically cultured on inorganic medium. The leaves normally produced only sporophytes from the'buds' formed at notched portions of lamina wherefrom no gametophytic outgrowths ever emerged. The latter were confined only to the stipe region and in association with some sporophytic and abnormal outgrowths of unspecified nature which die out shortly and the gametophytic outgrowths produced mature gametophytes on subculturing. Regeneration of gametophytes from cordate and spatulate thalli was also observed. Roots lacked the potentiality for regeneration. Owing to the presence of a number of chlorenchymatous cells surrounding the outgrowth proper, a multicellular origin has been assumed for it. The factors responsible for determining its nature—whether sporophytic or gametophytic—seemed to depend on the regulatory mechanism of genes or gene blocks in the same set of genome, switching off and on at appropriate times. The present work indicates that at least in some taxa, eg C. thalictroides carbohydrates do not seem to play a decisive role in the differentiation of sporophytes or gametophytes from excised leaves in culture,

title: Transducers for bio-telemetry
abstract: abstractTransducers using strain gauges have been described which can measure drip rate, flow, respiration rate and minute body displacements of the order of 2 microns or more. The output of the transducers is in the form of electrical voltage which can be telemetered by the use of the conventional techniques of voltage controlled oscillator, modulation and digital counting.
