title: In vitro antibacterial activity of the cationic proteins of buffalo polymorphonuclear cells
abstract: PMN cells play an important role in protecting host against invading micro-organisms by using O2 dependent and independent microbicidal systems. The later system in buffaloes has been examined by extracting PMN granular proteins and subjecting to GPC-HPLC column which resulted into'4 fractions and their relative antibacterial efficacies against E. coli and S. aureus were examined. Fractions III and IV were more potent than fractions I and II. The incubation of PMN cell granular proteins with E. coli and S. aureus caused greater binding/internalization offractions containing low molecular weight proteins (fractions III and IV) as assessed by GPC-HPLC. The ultrastructure of buffalo PMN cell revealed the presence of subcellular storage granules.

title: Vibrational spectra and thermodynamic functions of substituted chlorophyrimidine
abstract: The vibrational spectra of 2, 4, 6-trichloro and 2, 4, 5, 6-tetrachloro pyrimidines have been reported. The bands obtained are discussed assuming the molecules under C., symmetry groups. The group sensitive fundamental are compared with those of similar molecules already reported in literature. Thermodynamical functions have also been computed using the vibrational frequencies of these molecules.

title: Impulse noise trauma during army weapon firing
abstract: A 100 infanty personnel firing modern weapons such as the Anti Tank Guided Missile, 106mm Recoiless Gun (RCL), 84mm Rocket Launcher (RL) and 81mm Mortar were studied for the effect of impulse noise on the ear and the evolution of the Temporary Threshold Shift (TTS), Recovery Time (RT) and Permanent Threshold Shift (PTS) was traced.

title: Weathering configuration of Ariyalur—Pondicherry depression and its impact on seismic data
abstract: Low velocity layers are frequently encountered within the near surface stratigraphic formations in Ariyalur-Pondicherry depression of Cauvery basin, India. These layers affect the energy transmitted by the seismic source to the target horizons, introduce ambiguity in the computation of static corrections and impair the imaging of sub-surface structures of small amplitude. A comprehensive analysis of weathering configuration has been carried out for the region on the basis of uphole surveys and shallow refraction data. The variations in weathered layer thickness, sub-weathering velocity and elevations have been studied in detail. An interrelationship is established between these factors and seismic data quality. Finally, necessary measures are suggested for resolving these problems to improve seismic data quality at acquisition and processing stages. alluvium cover in a major part of Ariyalur-Pondicherry depression …

title: Studies on fertility and hatchability in Sire and Dam lines
abstract: The efficiancy of commercial farming of poultry is indirectly correlated with the efficiency of fertility and hatchability of eggs. Climatic conditions and other rearing facilities also play a significant role in egg fertility and hatchability. A study was under taken to ascertain fertility and hatchability status of synthetic strain of broiler population.

title: Effect of fertility levels and weed management on weeds, disease incidence and productivity of sesame
abstract: A field experiment was conducted during kharif season of 1992 at Indira Gandhi Krishi Vishwavidyalaya, Research Farm, Ambikapur (MP). The soil of the experimental field was upland, sandy loam in texture, acidic in reaction.(pH 6.2) and low in nitrogen (160 kg/ha) and phosphorus (9 kg! ha) and medium in potassium (230 kglha) content. The experiment was laid out in split plot design with three replications. Main plots consisted of three fertility levels and five weed control treatments constituted the sub-plots as given in Table 1. Variety Selection 5 was sown on 24 July, 1992 in 30 cm apart rows using 5 kg! ha seed rate. Fifty per cent ofnitrogen and entire dose of phosphorus and potash according to treatments were applied basal through urea, single super phosphate and muriate of potash, respectively. Remaining 50% of nitrogen through urea was top dressed at 35 days after sowing. Herbicide pendimethalin was …

title: Energy Scenario of Madhya Pradesh Agriculture and its Future Requirements
abstract: THE ENERGY requirements for crop production for the year 1990-91 were estimated and the area under different crops was projected for the year 2000-2001. The total energy needs in 1990-91 were estimated at 0.13 EJ (1 EJ= 1018J) and will be 0.26 EJ in 2000-2001, resulting 97 per cent over the energy needs for the year 1990-91. For irrigated crops, the main source of energy was fertilisers followed by electricity and diesel. However, for rainfed crops, the maximum energy was consumed in the form of seeds. In physical terms for the year 1990-91, there was a need for 2006 million units of electricity (1 unit-1 kwh), 116 million litres of diesel, 0.46 million tons of the nitrogenous fertilisers and 0.003 million tons of pesticide chemicals (active ingredients). There would be an increase in the requirement of seeds for paddy, soyabean, maize, wheat, gram, pea, mustard and potatoes whereas the requirement of seeds for sorghum, cotton, tur and sugarcane will decrease with respect to their needs for the year 1990-91.

title: Geotechnical Studies for Slope Design of a Large Opencast Coal Mine
abstract: 正 The paper discusses about geotechnical evaluation and slope design of one of the largest opencast coal mine, Gevra (India), which is currently 45 m deep with a strike length of about 5 km and annually produces more than 10 million tons of coal and more than 12 million m~ 3 of overburden/waste rock. Geotechnical investigations were carried out to design overall pit slopes for a depth of 180 m. The cores of four diamond drill boreholes were tested for representative engineering parameters for the pit design. A few direct shear tests on weak planes have also been done to determine the cohesion and friction angle. Simplified Bishop method and Sarma's method were used for stability analysis. It was found that 44 overall slope angle is safe for 180 m high slope. This slope steepening has resulted into saving of huge area of agricultural land around the mine, which otherwise would have been used for dumping of the overburden material. So, it helped for the betterment of the environment around the mine.

title: Weed Control in Irrigated Wheat under Low Hill and Valley Situation of Uttar Pradesh
abstract: Field experiment was conducted for five years 1989–90 to 1993–94 at Research Station Majhera, G. B. Pant University of Agriculture and Technology, Pantnagar, Nainital. Pelldimethalin at 1.5 kg/ha as pre-emergcnce caused maximum reduction in biomass production of weeds and increased the grain yield of wheat which was statistically at par with two hand weedings and isoproturon at 1.5 kg/ha applied as post-emergence under lower valley situation of U. P. hills. The highest mean (pooled basis) weed control efficiency of 74.6% was obtained with the application of pendimethalin at 1.5 kg/ha. Pendimethalin and isoproturon at their lower doses (0.5 kg/ha each) were also found significantly superior over the weedy check in increasing the grain yield.

title: Travel time approximation in anisotropic layered media
abstract: Most of the seismic data recorded in the field are P-wave reflection data for waves travelling very close to vertical. Therefore, it is assumed that these waves will not be affected by lateral variation of earth's subsurface i.e.,transverse isotropy.

title: Synthesis, Characterization and Biological Activity of Some Cobalt (II), Nickel (II), Zinc (II) and Cadmium (II) Benzoylhydrazine-Azide Complexes
abstract: A series of metal (II) benzoylhydrazine-azide complexes of the type M(BH)(N3)2.3H2O where M = Co(II), Ni(II), Zn(II), Cd(II) and BH = benzoylhydrazine, C6H5, C6H5NH2, have been prepared and characterized by elemental analyses, magnetic susceptibility, electronic and IR spectral data. The complexes are highly insoluble, powdery materials and decompose without melting. Co(II) and Ni(II) complexes are paramagnetic and octahedral. BH acts as a bidentate ligand coordinating through >C=O and -NH2 groups. BH, Co(BH)(N3)2.3H2O and Ni(BH)(N3)2.3H2O, screened against cyanobacteria Synechococcus cedrorum, a unicellular, non-nitrogen fixing mesophilic blue green algae, show moderate inhibition of algal growth and formation of protein, carbohydrate and photosynthetic pigments (chlorophyll-a, carotenoids, phycocyanin). Carbon fixation studies, using 14C labelled NaHCO3 solution indicate …

title: Seismic wave propagation and AVO analyses in anisotropic media
abstract: The study of offset dependent reflectivity plays vital role in identifying the hydrocarbon bearing reservoirs. Its success varies greatly due to several factors including velocity anisotropy. The characterstics of seismic signals depend upon the properties of the medium of propagation. In an anisotropic medium the seismic properties depend on the direction of wave propagation which may seriously affect the results of basic processing, interpretation as well as specialised studies like AVO analysis. The effect of velocity anisotropy is not only limited to the angular dependence of reflection coefficients but it also distorts the AVO signatures due to redistribution of energy along the wavefront of the wave travelling down to the reflector and coming up to the surface. An appropriate analytical expression of reflection coefficients using ray velocity has been derived in weak anisotropic condition. The variation of reflection …

title: Trace element characterization of Indian vegetarian diet and its constituents by instrumental neutron activation analysis
abstract: [en] Nutritive trace elements have been determined in a typical vegetarian diet and its various components. A hospital diet, pulses and vegetables have been characterised for 18 elements. Daily intake of elements have been compared with the International diet standards.(author). 5 refs., 1 tab

title: Radiotracer technique in adsorption study: part XII. Adsorption of Cd (II) and Hg (II) on hydrous metal oxides
abstract: [en] Adsorption behaviour of Hg (II) on hydrous manganese oxide and Cd (II) on hydrous bismuth oxide in aqueous solutions has been investigated as a function of concentration, temperature and pH of adsorptive solution applying radiotracer techniques. The influence of varying concentration of acid and some sodium salts on the uptake process of Hg (II) has also been studied. The nature and mechanism of adsorption along with radiation stability of adsorbents are discussed.(author). 7 refs

title: Development and pathogenicity of Heterodera cajani on a susceptible and moderately susceptible cultivars of pigeonpea.
abstract: The penetration by J 2 in roots of ICPL-87, a susceptible pigeon pea cultivar was earlier ie within 24 h as compared to in a moderately susceptible cultivar PDA-I where penetration occurred only after 24 h. The different stages of H. cajani were found earlier in ICPL-87 than in PDA-I. All the stages of the nematode persisted longer in PDA-I and the numbers of eggs/egg sac were lower than in ICPL-87. The reduction in shoot and root lengths, fresh and dry shoot weights, fresh and dry root weights, number of leaves and leaflet area was greater in ICPL-87 then in PDA-I in response to nematode infection. Similarly, the chlorophyll reduction in ICPL-87 was also more than PDA-I. Multiplication of H. cajani was higher in IPCL-87 and higher number of cysts, males, egg-sacs, eggs and juveniles/pot were recorded then in PDA-1.

title: Different approaches to evaluate brownstock washer efficiency
abstract: Brownstock washing has man {fold elfects in the pulp and paper industry. On one hand it produces clean pulp for paper making and on the other hand it separatej'black liquor. wjlids (Na~ salts and Lignin based solflte. y) from theplllp. Various type (~ fexpressions are available in the literature to aj'sess the performance (~ fa brownstock washer. These expressions are somewhat complex. Therefore these are not commonly practiced by the industry particularly the Indian pulp and paper industry. In this investigation some elficiency parameters are discussed. These parameters have been expressed in terms of simpler terms which can be readily measured like, porosity, inlet and outlet consistency, di. s·. WJlvedj'olidy~ f various streams, fibre production rate and density. Some interrelatio"'5 between various'e. fficiencyparameters have been established. A sample calculation based on industry data is given. Some common factors alfecting the performance of a brown stock washer are also listed. o

title: Effect of different salts of sodium on the yield and nutrient composition of pea
abstract: A greenhouse experiment was carried out with two soils namely Udic Ustochrept and Typic Haplustalfat Pura and Bara, respectively in Kanpur district of Uttar Pradesh. The characteristics of the soils are presented in table 1. Polythene sheet was fixed inside the coated earthen pots and 13 kg of thoroughly prepared soil was filled in each pot. Pea (cv. T 163) was used as a test crop. After complete germination, four plants in each pot were allowed to grow. Four salts of sodium of varying concentrations on the basis of mmol kg-I soil ofCI', sot, HCO)'and B as mg kg· 1 soil were applied through irrigation water in two equal instalments withina period of 10 days after complete germination (Table 2). The crop was harvested at maturily after which plant and soil samples were analysed.

title: Sulphide Stress Corrosion Cracking Behaviour of Some Low Alloy Steels
abstract: Resistance to sulphide stress corrosion cracking was evaluated for some low alloys steels (1Cr--0.5Mo, 9Cr--1Mo, 2Cr--1Mo) containing different amounts of carbon, Cr and Mo by using tensile specimens in 7 sub N H sub 2 SO sub 4 + 1 g/l thiourea solution. A certain combination of C, Cr and Mo has shown improved sulphide stress cracking resistance. The susceptibility of high Cr steel can be explained, at least in part, by the enhanced absorption of hydrogen. As Cr content increases, the solubility of H in steel increases drastically. This may be associated with the formation of chromium carbide which as incoherent interface with matrix, thereby providing large trap sites for H. Molybdenum has been found to improve the sulphide stress cracking resistance, at least up to 0.7%. The precipitation of molybdenum carbide is thought to be the reason for this improvement.

title: End point for sclerosis of esophageal varices.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Small esophageal varices are difficult to inject intravariceally and complete eradication of varices may not be therapeutically necessary. METHODS: A prospective study designed to compare the use of different end points of sclerotherapy ie (i) total eradication (grade 0)(ii) grade I varices or (iii) grade II white (IIw) varices, by stopping variceal injection when one of these was reached. The patients were followed endoscopically and clinically at 3-4 mo intervals. OUTCOME MEASURES: Variceal recurrence and rebleeding rates. RESULTS: Of 266 patients with portal hypertension (147 cirrhosis, 51 non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis, 68 extra-hepatic portal venous obstruction), 232 (87.2%) reached one of the three end points--six to grade 0, 96 to grade I and 130 to grade IIw. Among 212 patients followed up for a mean post-sclerotherapy period of 12.2 mo (range 3-48 mo), variceal recurrence rates, time intervals to recurrence and rebleed rates were comparable in patients with endpoints of grade I and grade II (white) varices (28.5% vs 38.9%, 10.8 mo vs 9.2 mo, and 7.7% vs 7.8%, respectively; all p= ns). Overall, 51 patients had interval bleed before reaching the end point--50 (98%) of them bled from grade III and IV varices while only one patient (2%) bled with grade IIw varices. CONCLUSION: Grade I or grade IIw varices should be acceptable as the end points for endoscopic sclerotherapy of esophageal varices.

title: Decline in chlorophyll and cane sugar by sugarcane mosaic virus and ratoon stunting disease in some varieties.
abstract: Chlorophyll content was measured in terms of mg/g fresh leaf of sugarcane variety CO 1148, CO 1158 and BO 3 infected with sugarcane mosaic virus (SCMV) and ratoon stunting (RSD) alone and in combination. Due to combined infection the loss in total chlorophyll was higher and it reached upto 52 per cent in the main crop and 45 per cent in ratoon crop.

title: Effect on immunoreactivity of gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH) in the GnRH-BSA conjugates of variable stoichiometry.
abstract: In order to render hypothalamic'self'decapeptide GnRH immunogenic, the GnRH and its azotized derivative were covalently coupled to the carrier protein, BSA. The azotization at histidine and or tyrosine of GnRH was carried out and characterized extensively. Three different molar ratios of GnRH/azo-GnRH with BSA were prepared and characterized by physico-chemical techniques. The conjugates purified by gel-filtration chromatography on G-100 and on gel permeation column using HPLC were subjected to molar ratio determination by amino acid analysis. The immunoreactivity of GnRH/azo-GnRH towards monoclonal and polyclonal antibodies was drastically hampered after conjugation. It is therefore suggested that in the GnRH-carrier conjugate, GnRH concentration should be determined carefully by using specific radioimmunoassay.

title: Calculation of spherical wave reflection and transmission coefficients and their application to shallow seismic exploration
abstract: The reflection and transmission coefficients of spherical waves vary strongly and in a more complicated manner to changing layer parameters than do the plane wave coefficients (figures 1 and 2). The difference between both types of coefficients increases when the radius of curvature of the wavefront approaches the order of the seismic wave Length. This is often the case in shallow seismic prospecting where the depth of exploration is between somet tens and a hundred meters.

title: Effect of moisture stress on seed germination of spruce
abstract: The results of the experiment conducted to study the effect of different levels of moisture stress indicated that the germination of spruce seed decreased as the moisture stress increased. The seed germination was 0.25% only at a moisture stress of-7.0 atm. Even the slighest moisture stress of-0.5 atm tended to decrease the seed germination'but the decrease in germination under the moisture stress of-O. 5 atm was not significantly different from control.

title: Response of spring planted citronella Java to dates and methods of planting and frequency of harvest
abstract: A field experiment on citronella Java conducted for two years at CIMAP Regional Centre, Pantnagar indicated that planting of citronella Java beyond 25 January led to considerable reduction in herbage as well as oil yield. The lowest herb and oil yields were recorded with March 12 planting. Flat and trench methods of planting being on par were significantly superior to ridge method. More than three harvests in a year did not increase the herbage and oil yields. dates and methods of planting and frequency of harvests on crop growth, herbage and oil yields of citronella Java.

title: Venation pattern in the sphenophyll Trizygia speciosa Royle from the Raniganj Formation
abstract: There has been a running controversy about the independent taxonomic status of the genus Trizygia vis-a-vis Sphenophyllum. The basic organisation of the foliage shoot in both the genera is apparently similar, except for the trizygoid leaf whorls in the former. The trizygoid leaf whorls are, however, not unknown in Sphenophyllum. The two genera can not be compared at the level of anatomy of the axes or the organisation of the fertile shoot as this information is not available for Trizygia. The venation pattern in leaves of Trizygia has been analysed in detail with a view to compare it with that of Sphenophyllum, when that information is forthcoming. The parameters chosen for analysis include length, width and area-index of leaves and number of dichotomies, ultimates and dichotomy levels.

title: THREE MICROLITHIC SITES FROM SAGAR DISTRICT (MP)
abstract: inadequately known as no systematic survey has yet been done. However, a few isolated discoveries of stone implements of different cultural periods suggest that the district has rich potential for the study of stone age cultural remains. The first discovery of stone age tools in the district was made by WL Wilson in 1886 (Brown 1917: 62-63). In 1959 RV Joshi (IAR 1958-59: 26) reported 25 implements of Lower Palaeolithic and a few Middle Paleolithic implements from the val-leys of rivers Sonar and Kopra. In the same year MG Dixit (IAR 1958-59: 72) reported a few microliths from the vicinity of Sagar. Middle Palaeolithic tools were also disco-vered from the valley of river Bila by KD Bajpai (IAR 1959-60: 70). Bajpai also reported a large number of microliths from Makronia, Bapson, Chandera and Reta (IAR 1960-61: 62). No detailed description of these discoveries has however been published.During March and April …

title: Effect of chromium on growth and utilization of iron and manganese by oat
abstract: Legumes have been found to respond to sulphur fertilization (Venkateswarlu 1971). Sandy soils are often deficient in available sulphur and crop responses to sulphur on such soils have been reported (Aulakh et ah 1977). Application of sulphur has been observed (Joshi & Seth 1975) to increase the availability of soil P. The present study was carried out to investigate the effect of sulphur fertilization on an arid sandy soil from two sources viz, pyrite and gypsum, on growth and nutrsent uptake by cowpea as well as on some soil properties (pH and available P status).A sample of bulk soil was collected from the Central Research Farm, Central Arid Zone Research Institute, Jodhpur. It was alkaline in reaction (pH 8.4), low in organic carbon (0.2%), available N (150 kg/ha), available S (6.5 ppm) and medium in available P (9.5 ppm). In a pot culture experiment three levels of S (10. 20 and 40 ppm) were applied from two …

title: Forms of Selenium in Soils of Western Uttar Pradesh
abstract: The amount of selenium occurring in soil affects the crops, and the animals which feed on them. When present in excess, it inhibits growth of plants, but at low level it has a stimulatory effect on some crops (Trelease & Trelease 1938). Since the soils of western Uttar Pradesh are neutral to alkaline, having free lime or gypsum and high salt content, some of these may contain potentially toxic levels of selenium (Kubota & AUaway 1972). The information regarding selenium status in the soils of this area is practically lacking and western UP being a cattle raising region the study was taken up.Four hundred and sixty surface (0-15 cm) soil samples were collected from Agra and Meerut regions of western Uttar Pradesh. From each district about 45 to 50 sites were selected for sampling. The soils were analysed for pH, electrical conductivity (EC), organic carbon, CaCOs and clay content by standard procedures (Jackson …

title: Hydromagnetic Ekman layer on free convection past an infinite porous flat plate
abstract: Free convection in a conducting liquid past an infinite porous vertical flat plate in a rotating frame of reference when the Hall current is present is considered. Exact solutions for the velocity and temperature fields have been derived. The effects ofM (Hartmann number),m (Hall parameter), andE (Ekman number) on the velocity field are discussed.

title: Kinetics and mechanism of adsorption of triton x‐100 on a reservoir sand
abstract: Adsorption of Triton X‐100 on a reservoir sand (characterised by chemical analysis and i.r. spectra to be silica) has been studied under field conditions. The adsorption behaviour is best characterised by Freundlich and Temkin adsorption models. The kinetics of adsorption is found to be very much dependent on temperature and the rate of adsorption shows an anti‐Arrhenius temperature dependence. The adsorption is proposed to proceed through Si—CH3 bond formation. Addition of common inorganic salts is found to cause maxima and minima in the adsorption isotherm and to change the shape of the isotherm.

title: Fracture of Titanium Alloy IMI 685 During Low-Cycle Fatigue
abstract: The fracture characteristics of alloy IMI 685 in the furnace cooled and aged (FC-A), oil quenched and aged (OQ-A) and water quenched (WQ) conditions tested in low-cycle fatigue (LCF) at room temp. were investigated. Widely different fatigue lives result in the three conditions at equal strain amplitudes. The crack initiation sites in smooth specimens have been traced from the orientation of fatigue striations in the fractured specimens using SEM. 12 ref.--AA

title: On n→ p+ e++ νe
abstract: Estimates for the rate of ΔB= 2 decay mode n→ p e+ ν e are discussed. It is suggested that experiment setups to study proton decay and n− n oscillations can provide limits on this mode.

title: Development of the flower of Pyrostegia venusta (Ker.-Gawl.) Miers (Bignoniaceae)
abstract: The premordia of the floral appendages are formed in acropetal sequence; however, there is an overlapping in the formation of petal and stamen primordial. The floral apex has a two-layered tunica in all stages of development. All floral appendages (bracts, sepals, petals, stamens and carpels) are initiated by periclinal divisions in the second tunica layer of the corpus may also contribute to the formation of stamen and carpel primordial. All appendages are characterized by apical meristem at least for a time and exhibit marginal initiating cells. The short clay x tube is formed by ontogenetic fusion of the bases of sepals, but the upper part of the corolla tube arises by ontogenetic union of originally free parts and the lower part by zonal or intercalary growth. The morphological nature of the placenta has been discussed and the present ontogenetic study suggests that it is an axial structure which morphologically …

title: Studies in bignoniaceae. VII. Wood anatomy
abstract: The wood anatomy of 17 species representing 14 genera has been investigated. The wood is diffuse porous. It is composed of vessels, tracheids, fibres, axial parenchyma and rays. The vessels are either scattered solitary or in radial or tangential multiples of two or three or in long radial chains. All the lianas and a few trees studied have two types of vessels with narrow and broad diameter. The vessels usually show a simple perforation plate. Two main types of xylem fibres, the fibre tracheids and the libriform fibres intergrade with each other. The xylem parenchyma is paratracheal, vasicentric and confluent to aliform. The rays are uni- or multiseriate, homogeneous or heterogeneous and their length varies in different species.

title: Termination of Pregnancy Is Second Trimester by Intrauterine Catheter
abstract: PIP: After briefly reviewing the published literature on second trimester abortion, the authors present the results of a series of 500 abortions conducted during second trimester by insertion of a catheter only. All patients aborted by the vaginal route, and no serious complications were encountered. 24 patients complained of bleeding which was easily controlled, and 20 patients had retained placenta, which was manually removed. This procedure is safe, simple, and inexpensive, an attribute to be taken into consideration in a poor country like India.

title: Synthesis and Properties of Some Unsaturated Esters of As (III) and Sb (III)
abstract: The unsaturated esters of As(III) and Sb(III) of general formula M [OC(RR′)CH[dbnd]CH[sbnd]R″]3 have been synthesized by the interaction of arsenic and antimony isopropoxide with various unsaturated alcohols in 1:3 molar ratio, respectively. All the compounds synthesized are colourless liquids which can be distilled under reduced pressure. The synthesized compounds were characterised by their elemental analysis, and i.r. and p.m.r. spectral studies. The molecular weights of these compounds in boiling benzene have been determined.

title: Shoot apex organisation and leaf development inRicinus communis L.
abstract: Cytohistologically the shoot apex ofRicinus communis is distinguished into five zones: (i) Tunica, (ii) Corpus, (iii) Flank meristem, (iv) Rib meristem, and (v) Cambium-like zone. The cells of the cambium-like zone are radially elongated and stretched across the apex from the base of the leaf. This zone is formed during the early part of the plastochron. The differentiation of this zone begins in the centre of the apex and proceeds outwards. It becomes fully developed by mid-phase. This zone is responsible for the differentiation of the node and elongation of the stem. Leaf initiation takes place in the second tunica layer and the leaf primordium increases in height by a group of subapical initials. Apical growth of the primordium ceases when it is about 120 microns high. The cells of the middle layers are derived by the periclinal divisions of both adaxial and abaxial hypodermal layers.

title: Additions to the Flora of Rajpipla Forest Division, Gujarat
abstract: In this paper 202 more angiosperms are listed of which 1 18 are dicotyledons and 83 are monocotyledons, based on collections made between 1965 and 1971 from different areas of the Rajpipla forest division. Such additions are due to (1) intensive exploration in all seasons and (2) two distinct types of vegetations (a) the dry deciduous type in hilly regions and (b) the scrub forest type in the un-dulating plains.

title: Further Contribution to the Flora of Rajpipla Forests, Gujarat
abstract: In the preseny paper an additional list of about 365 plants from Rajpipa forests is given of which 274 are dicoty1edons, 88 monocotyledous and 3 pteriphytes. The list is based on the collections made from Gora, Kevadia, Garadeswar and Surpaneshwar in December, 1966 and Dedbipada and Sagbara in August, 1967 to September, 1968. With the present list the total number of plants, so far, collected or noted from Rajpipa forest range is about 565.

title: Grasses of Sardhana
abstract: In this paper the authors have enumerated 48 genera and 59 species of grasses from Sardhana Tehsil in Meerut district. Of these 24 genera and 33 species belong to the subfamily Panicoideae and 19 genera and 26 species to the subfamily Pooideae. The tribes Paniceae and Andropogoneae have the largest number of species, ie, 17 and 15 respectively.

title: Khap Panchayats: Honor Killings In India
abstract: “This is wholly illegal and has to be ruthlessly stamped out. There is nothing honorable in honor killing or other atrocities and, in fact, it is nothing but barbaric and shameful murder. Other atrocities in respect of the personal lives of the people committed by brutal, feudalminded persons deserve harsh punishments. Only this way can we stamp out such acts of barbarism and feudal mentality. Moreover, these acts take the law into their own hands, and amount to kangaroo courts which are wholly illegal.”

title: Dc to Dc boost converter
abstract: In this paper converter use innovative technique, the loads power can be flexibly distributed between input sources. Also, charging or discharging of energy storages by other input sources can be controlled properly. The purpose of this project is to design and test a functional proof DC to DC boost converter. A microcontroller provides the necessary control signal to the switching circuit and it also monitors the input and output voltage levels. The input and output voltages are displayed on an LCD. Based on the input from a potentiometer, the microcontroller adjusts the duty cycle of the control signal thereby controlling the output voltage. An input voltage between 6-10.5 Volts can be given and the device can produce a maximum voltage of 25V. This device is particularly useful in situations where standard voltage requirements do not match user’s application.

title: MHD Effect on Free Convection Fluid Flow Past a Vertical Surface with Porous Medium and Radiation
abstract: The Present work analysis the effect of magnetic field on free convective flow of a viscous incompressible fluid past an infinite moving porous hot vertical plate in the presence of porous medium and radiation. The governing equations of motion have been solved by Laplace transformation technique. The effects of various parameters on the flow have been discussed with the help of tables and graphs.

title: Flextic: Trading time for discounts in cloud computing
abstract: Cloud computing aims to give users virtually unlimited pay-per-use computing resources without the burden of managing the underlying infrastructure. We present a system Flextic, which allows the user to benefit from a pricing model that offers flexibility at the requirements level, such as a tradeoff between different degrees of execution speed and execution price. At the same time, Flextic allows the provider to benefit from pricing contracts that guarantee the long-term usage of computing resources.This paper presents and evaluates Flextic. Flextic runs on top of cloud computing infrastructure and provides a job execution platform for users. The novelty of Flextic lies in the flexibility it offers: users can choose a price of job execution, which converges to zero if the user is willing to wait for a sufficiently long period. We evaluate Flextic on Amazon EC2. We use Flextic to manage various data intensive and compute …
